messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:27): fwiw, CORS now has http://dev.w3.org/2006/waf/access-control/#http-access-control-expose-headers

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:28): I think the only thing that is stopping it from moving on is some coherent explanation of how you should not run untrusted script in your own origin and then let it talk cross-origin
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:34): cool
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:35): the CORS adventure has been quite an odyssey
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:36): epic poems could be written about it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:37): a meeting was had / a proposal was made / done it seemed / but three more years await
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:37): now the rest of it...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:37): brilliant
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:38): take a break from spec writing and focus on the poetry for a while
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:38): you may be on to something
358972362a0d8c98d74cca6eb50a1c73 (11:38): I hope the media fragment journey won't be such an odyssey
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:38): tragic comedy
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:39): is the main form of narrative we often seem to find ourselves in
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:39): as far as work on technology standards
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:39): Yeah, and I was told it would be erotic fiction
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:40): Imagine my disappointment
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:41): is somewhat tempted to point out to Roy: "Didn't he just do that?"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:42): No point in getting in pissing matches with trolls
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:42): yeah, deleted the email
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:42): it's the thought that counts, I guess :p
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:44): I sometimes find myself wanting to just put a plague on both the houses
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:45): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Isn't that just your general God complex playing up again?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:46): there's clearly no god in this universe
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:46): only a demiurge
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:46): and I was thinking more in terms of what happened to Mercutio
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:46): In any case I think a plauge of hotly-worded-emails is the modern day equivalent of frogs, at least
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:47): http://www.w3.org/2000/09/dbwg/details?group=44977&public=1 -- pretty much all W3C old-timers
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:47): hotly worded e-mails are like the nurse in the play
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:47): comic relief
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:48): doesn't remember what happened to Mercutio, apart from the fact that he ended up dead
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:48): or like Quentin Compson
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:49): er, I mean Benji
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:49): I saw them as more like the priest. Well intentioned, but ultimatley responsible for the tragedy
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:50): or make that Benjy
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:50): not the dog
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:50): although if the story were told by a dog that would be maybe even be better
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:53): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: when you're back around, I wanted to ask about how to proceed with that MathML update for v.nu
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:54): based on my understanding from the offlist discussion, I have http://qa-dev.w3.org:8888/ confoir
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:54): *configured to only allow HTML markup in <mtext>
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:54): for now at least
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:55): unless/until whatever ends up being added to the HTML5 spec says otherwiser
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:55): MathML needs to be updated for this, not HTML5, I think
4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b (11:55): So now Roy is claiming that thousands of CMSes use Content-Language?

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:56): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I have had some offlist discussion about that, and it was pointed out to me that the MathML3 spec says this: "The draft HTML5 Recommendation, [HTML5], contains details for how MathML is included in HTML5 (and XHTML5)."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:57): http://www.w3.org/TR/MathML3/chapter6.html#interf.html
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:57): Hixie: never mind
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:58): btw, everybody, MathML3 is back at LC, with a deadline for comments of July 1
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:58): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, but not how HTML5 is included in MathML
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:58): (which is what the question is here)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:58): 4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b, according to Roy browsers are hardly relevant
4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b (11:59): I know that, but previously it's been vague suggestions that some unspecified CMS uses it
4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b (11:59): Thousands is quite a step up
4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b (12:00): I imagine you need a really loose definition of CMS for there to exist thousands of them

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:00): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: true. perhaps I need to make an LC comment to ask for text to be amended to the that: "And how HTML content in included in MathML content within HTML documents."
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:00): IS it actually only possible to change the selection in an element that has focus?
4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b (12:01): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: What if the element doesn't take focus?

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:01): 4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b: My reason for asking is that http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-canvas-api/2010AprJun/att-0054/2dcontext10-June-7.html#focus-management has setCaretSelectionRect which assumes the element with a selection is also focused

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:02): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I do now notice that sentence, "In the lax schema profile, elements from non-MathML namespaces are allowed in token elements, but not in other elements."
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:04): Oh wait, maybe the "or is not a document descendant of the element with whose context the method is associated" applies
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:06): Argh. Logic fail
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:08): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, hmm yeah, though note that if browsers are to follow the HTML5 rules it will also work in "MathML documents"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:08): there's no real distinction between those things in code
4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b (12:08): I'm not quite sure I understand the problem, but e.g. text can be selected and won't trigger focus events (but it does blur the previous focus owner, if any)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:09): 4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b, that can happen
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:09): 4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b: If I do "select all" does that necessarily have to focus the control where the text is being selected?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:09): 4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b, well actually, the document would have focus in that case so something is triggered (iirc)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:09): (assuming I am implementing with DOM)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:10): s/do/implement/
4d2a769942601baa26f55634a8eb251b (12:12): Besides, once you involve script they're definitely not connected, e.g. having a 'select text' button in the app UI
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:12): Nice example
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:12): hmm, anybody been following work on this doc? - http://www.w3.org/TR/xml-proc-profiles/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:13): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 maybe?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:13): see https://lists.webkit.org/pipermail/webkit-dev/2010-June/013250.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): Basically, the profile would be much like what is described as the
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): "minimum XML processor profile" except that reading the external
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): subset would not be required.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): indeed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:15): on the face of it, it seems odd that the minimal profile would require reading external markup declarations
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): hmm, there is actually also a "minimum XML processor profile" that's meant to be simpler than the "basic XML processor profile"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): but it still requires support for reading external markup declarations
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:17): really?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:17): silly
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:18): as far as I can see, those are the only profiles it permits
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:18): so browsers currently can't conform to this spec at all
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:19): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: i haven't seen that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:19): well, seems like it would be worthwhile to comment on it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:19): comments to <email/>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:20): can't find any mention of it in my public-xml-core-wg inbox
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:20): I guess maybe Alex Milowski is in that group
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:20): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: because it's a different group
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:20): http://www.w3.org/XML/Processing/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:21): not XML Core
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:26): "I don't think the text should even appear in the HTML standard until it has been implemented with some consistency" -- Roy T. Fielding
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:26): haha. How does he expect implementation to occur without a spec?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:27): it's certainly possible to implement something without a spec
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:27): even with some consistency
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:28): if the spec is a mental image?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:28): well, yes, but it requires reverse engineering
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:28): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yes. maybe that's what roy is advocating?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:40): guess he missed the part of history where we were doing exactly that and felt miserable
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:01): oh god
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:01): confusion all over
